Speaker: virtuosity
Dialogue: by  Eric Bernt  THIRD REWRITE   August 24, 1994

Speaker: parker barnes
Dialogue: His body is a running back's. His endurance a marathoner's. His face one you'd want for your own. He's in his 30s. If he was in his 20s, you'd still be jealous.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I can't get over how different you look.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Five years can be a bitch, huh?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Lady, move!

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Where's John?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Recital's over, asshole.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: SHIT!

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: What did Cox pull him out early for?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Barnes used to work for him when he was still a cop in the field, remember?

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Don't remind me.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: SOMEBODY.. .DO SOMETHING!

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: What the hell happened?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Lindenmeyer developed neural connectors that tap directly into the nervous system. If the simulator isn't calibrated properly, experiencing death in this level of VR is like experiencing death within a dream. The experience becomes real.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Simulations are supposed to give participants practice in realistic, dangerous scenarios while protecting them from the risks they are exposed to in the real world.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I was assured the problem was corrected.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: I did fix it.. I told you I did. I don't know why it happened again.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Again?!

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: My first two pairs of convicts suffered the same fate.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Why wasn't I told?

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Black book dollars, black book operation. You pay me for results, not how for how I get you there.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: I'll tell you one thing - there is no way in hell we should allow any real officers to train in this damn thing.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Then about all I've spent $37 million developing is a very expensive way to control the prison population.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: He...only had a year left on his sentence.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: How much do you think I care?

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: I'll walk him out.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Why'd.. .you pull me out?

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Donley started experiencing the attack for real. If I hadn't gotten you out, the same thing would have happened to you.  You may not believe this, Parker,

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: What the hell did you have to shoot the busboy for?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: He was a computer program for crissake.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: You were supposed to act as if everything was real.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Real, my ass. It's an overblown game.  Anybody ever catch that fucking psycho?

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Before you, nobody else had gotten close enough to Sid 6.7 to take a shot at him. Hell, nobody else had even been able to start tracking him before he got to them first.  New scar  you making it okay in there?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: I'm getting by.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: You've got to know I tried keeping you out of general population. Goddam politicians...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: I'm becoming something else, and it scares the hell out of me.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: But with the six months off I get for being your guinea pig, I've only got to survive another 17 years, 5 months, and 23 days.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Don't give up, Parker. Not ever.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: You know those cheesy Christmas cards of your family under that tree in your back yard you keep sending me every year?

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: What about them?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Do me a favor  keep sending them.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Take care, pal.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Hey Parker  I'm real sorry John boy got fried. What do you think Big Red's gonna do when he finds out you came back without his girl friend?

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: Did you recognize the son-of-a bitch who got away?

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: Think hard -- it'll come to you...

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: You embarrassed me in front of the highestranking law enforcement official in the country.  Do you have any idea how much money you just cost me?

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: The reason you insisted on testing my system with prisoners is because of the increased risks involved with increased realism.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Of the six prison inmates you've tested  all of whom have had at least some military or survival training - only Mr. Barnes is still breathing.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: I'm still making adjustments...

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: You've had a yearandahalf to make all the adjustments you want, Lindenmeyer.  Elizabeth Deane does not give second chances. Neither do I. You're fired.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: I'M WHAT?!

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: You are to turn over the Sid 6.7 program, and all its documentation, for immediate destruction. Is that understood?

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: I understand... I understand perfectly.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: How does he know who I am?

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: He hears...everything.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: As a matter of fact, I do.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: This is Wallace...

Speaker: red
Dialogue: Time to hurt...

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Fun's over.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: I still don't know why they wasted this fancy, new technology on you. Every time I fix you up, you only go and mess it up again.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Tell me how this feels...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: OW!

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: I'll dial it down a little.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: It'll never feel right.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: At least they work. Would you rather have no hands at all?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Sometimes.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Congratulations, Reilly...

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: As long as you keep overpaying me, I'll be the first to go into production on three, and four, as well.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: As long as they keep overpaying me, I'll keep overpaying you.  Just make goddam sure you can have 10 of them ready for deployment around the city by next month.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Mr. Wallace, I could have 10 of them ready by tomorrow.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: Do they have to look so...robotic?

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: At this stage, you either get form or function. You said she wanted function. I gave you function. What are you complaining about?

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: All they want to produce around here is mediocrity!

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: It was you, wasn't it?

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: You amped the neural connectors back up, didn't you?  You're the reason the convict died. You're the reason I got fired!

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: My God...

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: What do you expect me to do, put your character module in my pocket and just walk you out of here?

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: Hey, Reilly, Sheila 3.2's been asking for you...

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: The cuffs won't be necessary.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: No offense, ma'am, but I don't think that's such a good idea.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I would like the following three things in this order: your mouth shut, his cuffs off, and your ass outside the door. Any questions?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: You actually listen to all those tapes?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: How you feeling today?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: A little less than yesterday.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: In other words, par for the course.  How do you feel about the simulation you participated in yesterday?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: John died.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I know. I was there. I saw the whole thing.  If I was your therapist, I would have advised you against putting yourself back into that kind of situation.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: You're not my therapist. You're hear to study me. Face it  I'm nothing more than a lab rat to you.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: That's not true, Parker.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: If I had died yesterday, you'd have already dissected my brain and analyzed it to see if I carry any genetic predisposition toward violence.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: What was going through your mind when you killed the busboy?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Not much. He was just a computer program. Nothing more.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: You didn't see the expression you had on your face when you pulled the trigger. But I did.  You kind of liked it, didn't you? That thrill of going over the edge again. Of taking out an innocent bystander or two, as long as you got the target...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Go to hell.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: It was just like before, wasn't it? Wasn't it?  But you are making progress. Instead of killing seven people to get the one you're after, this time there was only one other person involved.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Enough!

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: GET OUT!

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: I don't have to do anything except survive. And it's taking everything I've got just to do that.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Oh, believe me, it is. It is...

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: HEY!!!

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: Show's over unless I get to see what you've been working on after hours.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: I haven't been working on anything.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: Do I get to see it or not?

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Sheila, don't go anywhere. I'll be right back.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: All my work is my finest.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: Get that fucking thing away from me!

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: You're...such a wimp.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: It's nanotechnology, isn't it? Machines the size of molecules...

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Coordinated by polymer neural net.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: It feels so.. .real.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: It's better than real. It's synthetic flesh. Synthetic blood. Synthetic organs...  It's a physiological machine.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: This is supposed to be years away.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: As far as the public is concerned, it is. The reason you got fired, and I got my second demo into production, is I'm a lot smarter than you. I never give my best stuff away.

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: How do you kill it?

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Separate the character module from the neural net...

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: Amazing. I hate to say it, but it is.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: I know.  I'm ready to incubate something a little more advanced than a coldblooded reptile. If you want to experience the future, meet me in my office in 15 minutes. And bring the Sheila 3.2 character module with you...

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: I think I understand what you have in mind...

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: You need a maid.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: What I need is a nymphomaniac.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: It feeds on what is basically amniotic fluid.  In eight hours, we are going to have ourselves one hell of a play toy.

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: Baby, what I'm gonna do to you...

Speaker: lindenmeyer
Dialogue: SID  NO!!!

Speaker: reilly
Dialogue: This... isn't.. .possible!

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: You're wasting your time. I'm not going to play any more of your goddam games.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Parker Barnes, I'd like you to meet Crime Czar Elizabeth Deane.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: It's too early in the morning for me to be cordial. You got any coffee?

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: I watched your simulation, Mr. Barnes. Very impressive. You know, you're the only one to ever go up

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Only because I got pulled out early.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Nobody else ever got anywhere near him. Nobody else... understands him like you do.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: These were taken inside LETAC an hour ago. Pretty pictures, aren't they?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: I've seen worse.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Name was Clyde Reilly. Hardware specialist.  LETAC surveillance cameras got a picture of the perp as he left the building.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: You mean a nanotech synthetic organism.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Whatever.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Can you kill it?

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: If you can catch him.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Think you can do it?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Not from in here.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: This is a full pardon. It authorizes your immediate release.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Recognize this? How would you like your old job back?

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Catch him and your record's clean.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: What happens if I can't catch him?

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: If Sid 6.7 hasn't killed you, we throw you back in here and you serve out the rest of your sentence.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: How do you know I won't run?

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: This is the newest technology approved for general implementation. It's called a locater implant. Every parolee gets one.  We're going to know where you are every second for the rest of your life.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: If you try to run, I'll hunt you down and kill you myself.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Yes or no, Mr. Barnes?

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: There's already a task force out looking for Lindenmeyer. Every other officer in the city will be hunting Sid right along with you.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: But only you will know he's not human.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Ms. Deane, you wanted to see me?

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: We have an emergency situation which requires somebody with expertise in criminal psychology. Under the authority vested in me by the President, I'm giving you temporary reassignment.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: What's the assignment?

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: You're going to put your theories to practice. I'm sending you into the field.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: What exactly am I going to be doing in the field?

Speaker: anesthetist
Dialogue: You are right on the border of his corpus callosuni.

Speaker: surgeon
Dialogue: He is under, isn't he?

Speaker: anesthetist
Dialogue: Won't stop him from dreaming, though...

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: This is Parker Barnes six years ago. The most decorated cop in the history of L. A. P. D. Special Investigations Division...

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: That's also where Mr. Barnes lost his arms to Mathew Grimes' booby trap. What's your point, Dr. Carter?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Letting a lunatic like Parker Barnes loose in the free world is like lighting a fuse. At some point, he will go off -- you saw what happened in the simulator. The risk to the public is unacceptably dangerous.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Not if you're with him every step of the way.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: The man played judge, jury, and executioner with eight people's lives. He lost control and is capable of doing it again.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: I understand the risks involved here. But there is nobody better qualified to go after Sid 6.7 than Barnes. And, there is nobody who knows him better than you. If a situation becomes volatile, you will find a way to quell it. I have complete confidence in you.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: I don't need a babysitter.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: What you need is a collar.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: She's going to help you understand

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: What she's going to do is get in my way.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: This is the personnel file on the programmer, Lindenmeyer. There might be something in it you can use.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: She wasn't part of the deal, Cox.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Fine  you want to stay here?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Their weapons missing?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Where's my gun?

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Be careful with it.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: You remember how to get to Toluca Lake?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: What are you doing?!

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Every day for the last five years, I told myself that lie.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: It wasn't a lie.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Every time I said it, it was. I never really thought I was going to make it.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: You all right?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: See, I'm a good liar.

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: As L. A. P. D. Officers continue gathering evidence at this grisly crime scene, you can only ask yourselves what kind of lunatic would commit such unthinkable crimes?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: You ready for this?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Don't worry. If I can't handle it, I'll just kill everybody.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: He was reenacting Charles Manson's LaBianca murders.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Manson didn't kill the first cops to arrive on the scene.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Whoever did this wanted to do Charlie one better  to improve upon what was already done.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Charlie? You say that like you're close, personal friends.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I've spent over 50 hours interviewing him.  The question is, what does Charlie

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: I know who would know.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: You drive well for somebody who hasn't done it in five years.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Learn anything from Lindenmeyer's file?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: He had a twin brother who was a musical child prodigy who died in an electrical accident at age eight. Lindenmeyer went into an emotional shell until was 17. All he did day and night was play the violin.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: What happened when he was 17?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Every music school in the country rejected him and he turned to computers.  Stay here.

Speaker: undercover
Dialogue: None, yet.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Mind if we take a look inside?

Speaker: undercover
Dialogue: Not until somebody gets a search warrant signed. It's Sunday. I don't think they've even found a judge, yet.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Do what you've got to do.  So will I...

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: You've got a problem with me carrying a gun?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Do me one favor  if you shoot at anything, make sure I'm nowhere near it.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Bang...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: You enjoy frightening me, don't you?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: You've studied me, now I'm studying you. Seems only fair, don't you think?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: This Lindenmeyer's a real piece of work.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Maybe after they catch him, you should write a book about him...

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I'm still working on it.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: I've been in prison, remember?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: The government must have figured there was no better person to create a psycho than a psycho.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Just like they figured there was no better person to catch one...

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I am the demon from the bottomless pit...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: ... here on earth to create havoc and terror. I am War, I am death. I am destruction. David Berkowitz,

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I am impressed.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: For murder, though it have no tongue, will speak with most miraculous organ.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Who said that?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Hamlet.  What's David Berkowitz got to do

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: He's part of the mix. Sid 6.7 is a composite.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Lindenmeyer put increasingly complex combinations of criminal psychological profiles together to develop the ultimate villain.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Creating a whole far more dangerous than the sum of its parts.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: But rather than selecting pieces from each individual, he simply let the stronger traits of each individual cannibalize the weaker ones.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: This is getting you pumped up, isn't it? This is like the World Series to you.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: As a matter of fact, it is.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Remember the bowling ball bag Sid carried with him in virtual reality?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Dahmer carried the head of one of his victims in a bowling bag for over a week. Kept it in his locker while he was at work in a candy factory.  We need to get a look at Sid 6.7's final profile.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: What we need to do is stop playing with computers and go catch the sonof-a-bitch before he kills anybody else.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: In order to find him, we have to understand what makes him tick...

Speaker: alexiev
Dialogue: Daryl Lindenmeyer was only here briefly, one semester at most. But he was singularly the most brilliant student I ever had in a classroom. He created programs so beautiful, so lyrical, they were almost like symphonies...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Can you tell us what's on the disc?

Speaker: alexiev
Dialogue: There is one program with approximately 1.3 million lines of programming. It is thoroughly secured, which is not surprising considering Lindenmeyer created it.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Think you can get into the program?

Speaker: alexiev
Dialogue: Hard to say  Lindenmeyer's protection mechanisms were always diabolically clever.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: You should see what he's been up to recently.

Speaker: businessman
Dialogue: You one of them New Age assholes?

Speaker: businessman
Dialogue: Listen, buddy...thinking big is fine.. .but you shouldn't forget where you come from, either.

Speaker: businessman
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: What are they doing in Los Feliz?

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: Madison lives two blocks from their present location.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: Why would they be going there?

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: I wish we could hear them.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: My engineers say the audio tap should be ready to field test in six months.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Not this one, but the next one. The one with the bicycle out front...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: I'll wait out here.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Give me your wrist.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Give me a goddam break. I'm not going to go anywhere alone.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: And I'm going to make sure of it.  Give me your wrist.

Speaker: karin
Dialogue: Mommy's home! Mommy's home!

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Grimes, you better not be the dominant.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Told you I wasn't going to go anywhere.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: How did you get your hand out?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Sometimes, I like being part machine.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I prefer keeping my professional life separate from my personal life.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: She's beautiful, you know?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Thank-you.  Her name is Karin.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Want to tell me the real reason we stopped at your house?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I told you, it was on the way and I wanted to change clothes.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: You should practice lying more often. You're awful at it.  Where to?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Sid 6.7 is no longer bound by his programming.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Now that he's in the real world, there are no longer limitations on his behavior like there were in virtual reality. Sid is going to evolve.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Sounds to me like a welleducated way of saying you have no idea what to do next.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: What I do know is that whatever he's becoming, Sid 6.7 is going to be even worse than he was before.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Then all we can do is stay mobile and alert. He's got to make a move sometime, and we've got to be ready when he does.  Welcome to police work. You better like coffee.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: I forgot what real coffee tastes like...

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: You know, considering you've only been out of prison for seven hours, you're readapting quite well.  Wait, I didn't mean that the way it sounded. I meant...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Don't worry about it, all right?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Dammit, I hate sounding so clinical all the time. All I meant to say was I thought you were doing well, but then I...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Relax. I know what you meant.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I ruin so many moments by analyzing them when I should just be living them.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Then why don't you start practicing and keep your mouth shut for a while?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: That's only a couple blocks from here.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: I'll meet you there.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Don't get out of the car.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Stop me.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Parker! PARKER!  Shit!

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: What the hell's going on?!

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: This is my area of expertise.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: What did you do to those people?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Being on the street's a little different than sitting in an office all day, isn't it?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Enjoying yourself?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: You know I am.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: This isn't a game, Parker!

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Tell him.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: That who I think it is?

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Call me whatever you want, asshole.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: The only thing I want to hear is your silence.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: You and me have nothing in common.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: You have nothing in common.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Still got your gun?

Speaker: traffic cop
Dialogue: You better be a cop, pal!

Speaker: traffic cop
Dialogue: Show me...

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: Nail the fucker.

Speaker: parker
Dialogue: What's the problem?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: I'm doing the best I can!

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: I forgot what it's like to have you on the streets.

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Any sign of Lindenmeyer?

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: None. He could be hiding, he could be helping Sid, or could be in little pieces on Santa Monica beach.  Any idea what Sid's going to do next?

Speaker: madison
Dialogue: Until we know what new influences are affecting him, we can't be sure.

Speaker: cox
Dialogue: In other words, we collectively don't know shit.

Speaker: wallace
Dialogue: I will never forget the first time I saw the photos from the crime scene.

Speaker: deane
Dialogue: The media has caught wind of his pardon. Unless Mr. Barnes starts giving me some tangible results, I'm going to put him back in his cage.

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: Police now believe there to be a connection between the grisly Toluca Lake murders yesterday afternoon, and the hostage situation which occurred last night in a downtown bar...
